title: 108_s2167
content: The Lewis and Clark National Historical Park Act of 2004 establishes the park to preserve historic, cultural, scenic, and natural resources related to the Lewis and Clark Expedition in the lower Columbia River area. It also commemorates the winter encampment of the expedition in 1805-1806 after crossing North America. The Lewis and Clark National Historical Park Act of 2004 defines key terms such as "map," "Memorial," "Park," and "Secretary." The Act establishes the Lewis and Clark National Historical Park to preserve resources related to the expedition and commemorate their winter encampment in 1805-1806. The Lewis and Clark National Historical Park is established in Washington and Oregon, including the Memorial site, Fort Clatsop lands, and parcels along the Columbia River associated with the expedition's arrival at the Pacific Ocean. The Lewis and Clark National Historical Park includes sites related to the expedition's arrival at the Pacific Ocean in 1805, such as "Station Camp," "Clark's Dismal Nitch," and "Cape Disappointment." The map of the park is available for public inspection. The Secretary has the authority to acquire land, interests in land, and improvements within the park boundaries through various means, including donation, purchase, exchange, or transfer from federal agencies. The Secretary can acquire land, interests, or improvements within the Lewis and Clark National Historical Park through donation, purchase, exchange, or transfer from federal agencies. Consent of the owner is required for acquisition, except for corporately-owned timberland in a specific area. If the owner agrees to sell timberland, a memorandum of understanding is entered into regarding the acquisition process. The Secretary can acquire land within the Lewis and Clark National Historical Park through various means. The owner's consent is required, except for corporately-owned timberland. The Secretary shall transfer management of Federal land at Cape Disappointment, Washington, within the Park to the Director of the National Park Service. The Secretary can acquire land within the Lewis and Clark National Historical Park through various means. The owner's consent is required, except for corporately-owned timberland. Land at Cape Disappointment, Washington, within the Park, shall be transferred to the administrative jurisdiction of the Secretary if the Federal agency does not need it. All withdrawals of the 20-acre parcel depicted as "Memorial to Thomas Jefferson" are revoked. The Secretary will establish a memorial to Thomas Jefferson on a specific parcel of land. Additionally, the Secretary may enter into an agreement with the State of Washington for the administration of Cape Disappointment State Park within the Lewis and Clark National Historical Park. The administration of Cape Disappointment State Park within the Lewis and Clark National Historical Park may be handled by the Secretary. The Secretary administers the Park in accordance with applicable laws, prepares a management plan within 3 years, and may enter into cooperative management agreements for the Lewis and Clark Expedition sites. The Secretary can enter into cooperative management agreements with officials in Washington and Oregon for the Park. SEC. 6. REPEALS; REFERENCES. Public Law 85-435 (72 Stat. 153; 16 U.S.C. 450mm et seq.) is repealed. Any reference to Fort Clatsop National Memorial shall now be considered a reference to the Lewis and Clark National Historical Park. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums necessary to carry out this Act are authorized to be appropriated. This Act establishes the Lewis and Clark National Historical Park in Washington and Oregon.
